description: This two-semester second-level writing course aims to guide students to (1) practice basic academic writing convention, (2) sharpen analytical essay writing skills, (3) enhance essay coherence and cohesion, and (4) develop a clear writing style. The course will familiarize students with proper academic language and convention to compose five-paragraph short essays on the following five modes of writing: argumentation, definition, causal analysis, process analysis, and comparison and contrast. In addition to the different analytical modes of writing, the course will introduce students to organizing and editing strategies to fine-tune their essay writing. On the one hand, students will learn how to apply principles of coherence and cohesion in their writing to maintain consistent claims and to offer logical transitions at the levels of ideas, sentences, and paragraphs. On the other hand, students will learn how to develop a clear writing style by avoiding common sentence errors and improving concision and specificity in word choice and sentence formation.
goals: 1.　To help students student develop their ability to express themselves in writing essays in English
2.　To help students write various kinds of essays in a well-organized manner
syllabus:
**Intermediate Writing in English - Sophomore Majors -** **Spring 2019**

**Time:** Fridays, 1:20-3:10                            **Classroom:** Ching 302 

**Objectives**: This course is designed to help students further develop their ability to express themselves in written English following on from the work done in the previous semester.

*   First, **the basics of essay writing** will be re-examined by looking at both **how to make effective sentences and word logic** while a series of **writing activities** will be undertaken to practice **writing fluency** and examine **writing for specific purposes** such as resumes and creative writing pieces.
*   This will be followed by an introduction to **writing about the Visual Arts**, which will involve critically analyzing works of art and includes **a trip to a modern art museum**.
*   In the latter half of the course, the focus will be on **how to construct an academic research paper** going through the process of **writing a competent paper**, from choosing a topic, constructing **interviews and questionnaires**, to writing a bibliography and documenting sources. By the end of the course, each student should be able to write a well-organised, focused, logical research essay of at least Freshman English-speaking university standard.

**Optional Textbook:** Wyrick, Jean (2012). _Steps to Writing Well. 12th Edition_ Colorado State University: Wadsworth.

**Materials:** One **“Writing Journal”,** which is to be used for note-taking, free-writing, assignments, essay writing and optional writing practice.

**Guidelines and Requirements: The Rules!**

1.  Punctual attendance is required. Talk to me if you have a problem attending or couldn’t attend class.
2.  Actively participate in class discussions.
3.  You need to **submit** your **work _several times_** during the semester.
4.  **Homework and writing** assignments **must** be done and be on time.
5.  Smartphones, tablets, etc, must be **turned off** unless needed in class.
6.  **No eating** during class, but **drinks** **are allowed**.
7.  **Optional Writing Practice -** Besides essays and assignments, students are **encouraged** to practice writing at every opportunity. They can do so in their “Writing Journals”, and will be reviewed for **extra grade**.

**Grading Policy****: The Business!**

Students’ term grades will be given based on the following aspects:

1.  Attendance/ Participation: 10%
2.  Classroom Assignments (e.g. peer reviews) : 10%
3.  Writing Assignments: 20%
4.  Visual Arts Essay: 20%
5.  Interviews/Questionnaire: 20%
6.  Research Essay: 20%
